intro: Camelina alpkoyensis, commonly known as the alpine camelina, is a flowering plant native to high-altitude regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The plant is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and heart-shaped leaves, adapted to thrive in cold, arid environments. It produces small, oval seeds that are often used in traditional medicine and as a source of oil. Camelina alpkoyensis plays a vital role in the ecological balance of its native habitats.
